ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

IMPORTED LIVESTOCK
(Free from harmful chemical and biological promotants)


    1. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the increasing use of growth promotants in livestock production, what steps are being taken by his Ministry to ensure that the imported livestock are free from dangerous chemical and biological promotants.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Primary Production Department carries out regular checks to ensure that imported livestock and meat are free from harmful chemical and drug residues. The checking system involves first approving overseas farms and meat processing plants for exporting livestock and meat to Singapore. This is followed by inspections at the point of import in Singapore, using sampling methods.

    Overseas farms accredited for export of live animals to Singapore are allowed to use only approved drugs and chemicals. These must be used according to procedures recommended by veterinarians and manufacturers.

    When imported livestock are slaughtered in our abattoirs, samples are taken for laboratory tests. Samples of imported frozen and chilled meat are also taken at point of entry for testing. The Primary Production Department keeps the test records of individual overseas farms and meat processing plants for monitoring.

    Sir, the present system does not apply to live poultry from Malaysia. The Primary Production Department is aware of the dangers to consumers arising from increasing and improper use of chemicals and drugs in modern poultry farms. It is working closely with the Malaysian Department of Veterinary Services to develop an accreditation scheme for poultry farms in Malaysia. This will enable PPD to inspect farms which export eggs and live poultry to Singapore to ensure that these products are safe for our consumers.

CONSTITUTION OF THE REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE
(AMENDMENT) BILL
(As reported from Select Committee)


    Order for Third Reading read.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Third time."

    The Report of the Select Committee as well as the Bill, as revised by the Select Committee, was presented to Members on 15th March, 1990. I am sure all Members have read and studied the Report and the reasons given for the decisions taken by the Select Committee. I therefore do not propose to make a lengthy speech, but only to highlight the main points.

    I propose to separate my comments into two categories: areas where changes were made to the original Bill, and other areas where the Committee decided not to make any change. There are four areas where the Select Committee decided changes should be made to the Bill.

Column: 1014



    The first concerns the "sunset" clause concept to the Bill. Members will recall that during the Second Reading, I suggested the idea of weaving a "self-destruct" or "sunset" clause into the Bill. I did so in order to accommodate the reservations expressed by some MPs over the Bill. My main objective was to urge them to try out the concept of NMP for the remaining period of this parliamentary term. The amendment to the Constitution will lapse automatically, unless it is re-enacted.

    During the Select Committee hearing, one representor graphically pointed out that such a "sunset" clause was like casting a "death wish for a new born baby". He was strongly against having such a clause in the Constitution which he regarded as the supreme law of the land. He argued, quite correctly, that if the system of NMPs was found unworkable, a future Parliament could always amend, or abolish it altogether. While I agreed with him, I nevertheless felt that we should have a mechanism which did not permanently and automatically require all future Parliaments to have NMPs.

    I therefore suggested that instead of a "sunset" clause, each Parliament should be given the discretion to decide if it wished to have NMPs for the term of that Parliament. It would determine this by a resolution; if it did not so resolve, then there would be no NMPs in that Parliament. This approach will give us some flexibility in trying out the NMP scheme. While the NMP provisions can be set out in the Constitution, they will not bind all future Parliaments to appoint NMPs.

    The Select Committee agreed with this variation. Accordingly, the Bill as revised by the Committee provides each Parliament with the discretion to determine whether it wishes to appoint NMPs. This is to be found in section 1 of the Fourth schedule. This discretion will be exercised by a resolution adopted by each Parliament within six months of its first meeting after a general election. NMPs will be appointed within six months of such a resolution. If no such resolution is adopted, no NMP will be nominated during the life of that Parliament.

Column: 1015



    Now, I move on to the procedure for selecting NMPs. The Committee weighed the pros and cons of various proposals to change the procedure for selecting NMPs, for example, whether there should be open discussion and voting by all the Members of the House on the nominees or whether there should be secret voting. The Select Committee did not accept these ideas and has given its reasons in its Report.

    However, the Select Committee did recognise that there was value in the Special Select Committee obtaining the views of other MPs before it made its final recommendations to the President. Accordingly, a change has been made to the Bill whereby the Special Select Committee will be obliged to consult the general body of Members of Parliament, individually or otherwise, before deciding on the names to be submitted to the President. This is provided for in section 2(3) of the Fourth Schedule.

    This change enables the Special Select Committee to benefit from the views and comments of the Members who may have specific knowledge of particular nominees, without the whole House having to meet and publicly debate or vote on individual names. The details of the manner of consultations have not been spelt out in the Bill. It is best we leave these administrative details to the Special Select Committee to decide. Such consultation should, of course, be to the extent possible or practical for it may not always be possible to consult all MPs, for example, MPs who are abroad.

    Thirdly, on the criteria for selecting NMPs, the Select Committee decided that the Bill should incorporate some criteria. This will not only guide the Special Select Committee in its deliberations but will also help members of the public when they propose nominees for consideration of the Special Select Committee. The criteria are spelt out in the amended section 3(2) of the Fourth Schedule, which reads:

    'The persons to be nominated shall be persons who have rendered distinguished public service, or who have brought honour to the Republic, or who have distinguished themselves in the field of arts and letters, culture, the sciences, business, industry, the professions, social or community service or the labour

Column: 1016

movement; and in making any nomination, the Special Select Committee shall have regard to the need for nominated Members to reflect as wide a range of independent and non-partisan views as possible.'

    The final change the Committee made to the Bill is that an NMP should vacate his seat before contesting a by-election where he contests on a party ticket. The original Bill did not require him to do so. The reason for the change is that it is not possible for an NMP to contest a by-election on a party ticket without his non-partisan image being affected. This requirement will not apply to an NMP standing for a by-election as an independent candidate as the same reason does not apply to him.

    Let me now turn to certain aspects which were raised during the hearings of the Select Committee but where the Committee decided to make no change to the Bill.

    First, concerns the question of whether NMPs should be permitted to hold political office. The original Bill does not prohibit an NMP from being appointed as Minister or other office holder. The Select Committee decided not to change this. Now, Members may recall what I said during the Second Reading and I quote:

    '... it is not the intention of Government that nominated MPs should be eligible to become Ministers or other office holders. The principle that office holders must come from the ranks of elected MPs will remain. If the provisions of the Bill are not specific on this point, suitable amendments can be made.' [Hansard, Vol. 54, No. 8, Col. 698].

    This is still my intention. The Government does not intend to appoint NMPs as Ministers or other office holders. But when I looked into the future, I wondered whether it was necessary or desirable to expressly prevent a future government from appointing an NMP as Minister. Many established democracies can and do regularly appoint Cabinet Ministers from the non-elected members of their legislature. Notable examples are the United Kingdom, France and Malaysia. If these countries, which have a bigger population and a bigger Parliament, need to appoint non-elected members as Cabinet Ministers from time to time, the reason is even more cogent for Singapore which has a Parliament of only 81 Members.

Column: 1017



    In coming to this decision, my guiding principle is what is in the national interests. For a country to be well run and the people to enjoy growth and prosperity, it must have effective government. This means having suitable people to do the specialised complex jobs like Finance, Trade and Industry and Law. If there is no elected MP who can do such jobs adequately, it is in the people's interest that a competent person is appointed to do so from the non-elected MPs.

    A government may also consider it useful to appoint a Minister in charge of the Arts. The best person need not necessarily be a politician and a government may wish to draw upon the very limited talent pool in the arts to appoint such a Minister, rather than have a politician without a real interest in the arts to do the job.

    The Select Committee is convinced that regardless of the intention of the present Government on this matter, it would be wrong to deprive future governments of this element of flexibility of appointing some NMPs as office holders.

    The Select Committee also deliberated on whether NMPs should sever ties with political parties. It decided that it was unnecessary to specifically require an NMP to do so. It felt that it was far better to leave to conventions and practice to evolve.

    On voting rights, the Committee decided to make no change, ie, NMPs will have the same voting rights as NCMPs. The reason was simple. The absence of voting rights would reduce the status of NMPs and discourage serious-minded persons from serving as nominated MPs.

    As Members can see, the Committee has made certain important changes to the Bill. It may not have made all the changes which all Members or representors to the Select Committee would have preferred. But I believe that Members will agree that we have been as accommodating as possible. I hope that Members will view the revised Bill more positively than the original Bill. Like all new proposals, people have their reservations. When I first pro-

Column: 1018

posed the concept of Medisave in this House, some sections of the public and also some MPs had their reservations. Likewise, when we introduced the concept of GRCs. Both Medisave and GRCs have worked, to the benefit of the people. Suppose we lacked foresight and the courage to propose and implement them. Would we be better off today?

    Again, I say, give the NMP scheme a try. If we do not try, we will never see the merits of the scheme. This Bill does not bind every future Parliament to have NMPs. If the demerits outweigh the merits, the next Parliament need not carry on with the scheme.

    Finally, let me thank all those who made contributions to the work of the Select Committee through their written representations and appearance before it. They made many valid points which, together with the views expressed in this House, have helped the Committee to improve on the original Bill.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the NMP proposal was first raised in Parliament, I was totally unhappy with the whole concept. After the First Deputy Prime Minister suggested a "sunset" clause or a "self-destruct" clause and proposed to call NMPs "Parliamentary Counsellors", I took time to reconsider the proposal. I consider these major concessions made by the First Deputy Prime Minister, concessions that are made by a listening leadership. I thought I could come on board, as called by the First Deputy Prime Minister. But having read the Select Committee's Report, and here the First Deputy Prime Minister is very right, I still have reservations and must state them at the outset.

    Since this House has already accepted the proposal and is now debating only on the merits and demerits of the scheme and on its details, I shall have to deal with these points as raised in the Select Committee's Report. Firstly, the recommendation that each Parliament should decide for itself whether it wants NMPs. My question

Column: 1019

to the First Deputy Prime Minister is: what does he mean by Parliament should decide for itself? If the Whip is again not lifted, then the answer is a foregone conclusion. This amendment is thus in effect a non-event, and we must realise that Parliament is in actuality left with no choice. We are back to square one. Perhaps the First Deputy Prime Minister will comment on this.

    Secondly, selection of NMPs. I am for a secret ballot. I am for this idea. Why? Because we do not want to embarrass potential NMPs. On this, I agree with the Select Committee. Discussing the merits and demerits of an individual will be unacceptable. I guess here the implication is that MPs are expected to be thick skin and NMPs are supposed to be very sensitive people. However, with a secret ballot, the result need only be made known to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, and the list of successful candidates as announced. The counter argument is that a secret ballot is not a usual or normal procedure. To quote the Committee's Report, "a radical departure from the established procedures." In answer, let me say that we have been amending procedures in our House to suit our own unique situation. Unusual measures and proposals call for unusual procedures. Let us move on and not be held back by tradition for its own sake. As the First Deputy Prime Minister has mentioned, the Medisave and GRC schemes have proved successful. So we are moving in this direction, let us go and take another brave step. Move on to a secret ballot.

    On the question of whether NMPs should be permitted to hold political office, my answer here is a categorical no. A party aspiring to form the government must ensure that it has the necessary candidates. A major factor in the electorate's mind when they go to the polling box is whether the party that he or she is voting for can form the next government. By allowing this, we may inadvertently be telling the electorate, "Do not worry. After the election, I will find you a good Law and Finance Minister, even though at this present time I do not have one to offer you." The art and politics of fielding candidates should be able to provide the leeway to ensure that Ministers for specialised port-

Column: 1020

folios be elected. There are constituencies or wards that are marginal and there are also so-called "safe" constituencies.

    Office holders must be accepted by the public and must work to win the public's trust and confidence. Trust and confidence of the public, how is this reflected? Except at the polling box by votes.

    Ministers cannot be merely able technocrats. They must be much more than this. They must have the confidence and trust of the public. However, if the fear is that "effective functioning of government" may be affected if we do not have a good Law or Finance Minister, then I feel that the amendment should in good faith categorically state that this Bill will only allow for the appointment of the NMP as Law or Finance Minister to the exclusion of all else.

    I find the argument for the appointment of an NMP as a Minister in charge of the Arts very difficult to accept. We were not a nation that used to sing, but now we are a singing nation. "Sing Singapore" is an overwhelming success. And the Minister for Communications and Information and the Minister for Community Development are by no means artistes at singing. We have often stated that we have an able and efficient civil service. I am sure that all our Ministers give due cognisance to the advice of our senior civil servants. The civil service is complementary to the politicians. It is not as if we do not have any fall back position. We have this.

    After listening to the First Deputy Prime Minister, I am still a little bit confused. He says that he does not intend to appoint NMPs as Ministers or other office holders. I await further clarification. That means he is making the provision now to allow them to hold political office but he does not intend to appoint them. Maybe he can clarify what this means.

    Next, coming to the point whether NMPs should sever all ties with political parties, the Report states:

    'NMPs should be, and be seen to be, non-partisan with no affiliation with any political party.'

Indeed, if an NMP is to give views that would help this House make better

Column: 1021

decisions, then this principle must be closely adhered to. I could not agree more with the Select Committee. Thus, on appointment the NMP should formally resign from membership of a political party. This is in line with the statement that the NMP should be required to be seen to be non-partisan. While it is also true that the act of resignation will not change the NMP's political philosophy or his sympathy for his party, resignation is still important, so that the NMP will not feel obliged to take his party's stand in Parliament. He will not be answerable to his party or beholden to his party. This very problem of finding non-partisan persons with no affiliation is one of the arguments against the NMP concept. However, as it has been accepted, the Special Select Committee will now have to seriously consider ways to overcome this. Then only will the NMP scheme gain credibility.

The NMP standing for elections

    Sir, for the NMP to blossom as a respected person to be reckoned with and to be resected by both Members of this House and the public, we should not over protect him. Protect him from an embarrassment before appointment, yes, I agree. However, when he decides to enter the political arena in total, even as an independent candidate, he should not only resign his NMP position, but he should also be barred from ever being appointed again as an NMP. He has already made his position amply clear. He is willing of his own volition to enter the political foray and he therefore should no longer enjoy the protection of this House. The NMP who stands for election is no longer a member of an endangered species and thus he deserves no special privileges or protection.

    In closing, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I add that this debate has far greater dimensions than merely discussing NMPs. It is about the role of Parliament, the responsibility of office holders and governing by consensus. PAP Backbenchers have often been urged by the party leadership to be constructively critical and not to be "yes" men. The party does not want this and neither does the electorate.

Column: 1022



    During the Second Reading of the Bill, the First Deputy Prime Minister said that he wanted to:

    ' ... encourage participation to build consensus, to accommodate alternative viewpoints and dissent.'

To go one step further, the electorate also does not want the Opposition to be "No" men, to disagree with everything that the Government does. However, after the last debate on this issue, there were some who expressed the view that if one disagrees with party line, then one should resign. I cannot disagree more. With a more educated generation, do we want to encourage this opt-out philosophy of life? Disagree with party, resign from party. Disagree with employer, resign from company. Disagree with Government, then what? Resign from Singapore? Emigrate? I believe that we must not become a generation or a nation of quitters. Out of discussion and disagreement may come out better ideas. Here I agree with the First Deputy Prime Minister when he said: "Do you agree or do you not agree with this intent of mine, ie, to do something which will allow us to forge consensus?"

    I thus hope that at the end of today's sitting we can all go home more convinced, if not converted, of this NMP scheme. The First Deputy Prime Minister has said, "Give it a try." Do we have any choice? But I would like to reassure him that we will give it a try very positively and we will try to make it work.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): The Select Committee's recommendation that each Parliament will have the discretion whether or not to have nominated MPs, in my view, is a correct and wise move. If a resolution is passed in Parliament that there be Nominated MPs, then the nominated MPs would be made more welcome in this Chamber. The decision whether or not to have nominated MPs would be the decision of the Members of Parliament. Additionally, such a resolution means that the nominated MPs will have some kind of legitimacy. After all, if it is a new Parliament passing a resolution that they be nominated, then to that extent they do have certain status, legitimacy, in this Parliament. So in my view it is an appropriate move to make.

Column: 1023



    But, Sir, I have three questions which I would like to raise with the First Deputy Prime Minister and seek his clarification. The first is the procedure for the nomination of NMPs. I agree that it would be cumbersome to debate the qualities, the characters, the experiences of all the names which would be submitted by members of the public. That is not desirable. But if the Special Select Committee short lists from the nominations of the public, then I would suggest that the shortlisted candidates be made known to Members of Parliament and that their names and their qualifications be discussed in various forums. The Special Select Committee should shortlist more than the required number of NMPs. And this short list, in my view, should then be put to a secret ballot. I agree with Dr Arthur Beng that the shortlisted candidates should be put to the vote so that each Member of Parliament can then decide for himself or herself which of this list of candidates should be nominated NMPs in this Chamber. The Report mentioned that this would be a radical departure. But since we are making a Constitutional amendment, then there should be no problem if we think it is desirable that the shortlisted candidates be subject to a secret ballot by this Chamber.

    The second issue relates to the information to be made known to the public concerning the shortlisted candidates. I think the public should know who these shortlisted candidates are, their qualifications, background, their experiences and so on. If members of the public through various forums would want to make strenuous objection for very strong reasons, then I think they should be given the opportunity to make known their objection. They are not voting on the shortlisted candidates. But if they have a serious objection and they have information which the Special Select Committee does not have, then it would be a useful exercise if we allow the public a say in the list of candidates to be put up. I hope this is possible.

    Thirdly, the question of their political affiliation. The original intent of this proposal, Sir, was that non-partisan independent people would come into this Cham-

Column: 1024

ber to debate on various issues, to make recommendations, and they should not be constrained by any party or political affiliation. Here again, I agree with Dr Arthur Beng that the shortlisted candidates should resign from any party membership of any political party. Otherwise it would compromise their position. Party membership may be known to his friends or her friends and the word goes around that he is a member of this party or that party. He is no longer a non-partisan person. So the integrity and the non-partisanship of such nominated MPs must be maintained.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah)( In Mandarin): Sir, during the Second Reading of the Bill I suggested that there are three points which should be considered. Firstly, we should consider the merits of NMP in the light of the ratio of Government MPs to Opposition MPs in future Parliaments. At present, the great majority of seats are occupied by the Government Party. Under these circumstances, I agree with the First Deputy Prime Minister's view that NMPs can help reflect the people's views because they are not like the PAP Members who are subject to the Whip's direction. But I feel that when Opposition MPs increase in number, the NMPs would lose their most meaningful justification and the number of NMPs should be reduced.

    Secondly, I do not think that an NMP should have the right to be appointed as a Minister. This is so because our Parliament has vested in our Ministers very substantial powers. Presently the Ministers are like other MPs. They have to go and face the electorate every five years to find out what the people think of their policies. Every Minister has this concern in his mind when exercising his power. Therefore, I support the idea expressly stipulating in the Bill that NMPs should not be appointed Ministers, which is very appropriate.

    The third point is how to prevent a future government from making use of NMPs to strengthen their political power. The Select Committee had several suggestions incorporated in the amended Bill. Here I have two points to highlight. First, allowing every new Parliament to decide on the

Column: 1025

question whether they want to have NMPs or not. Second, giving the right to NMPs to be appointed Ministers. On the second point, the First Deputy Prime Minister indicated at the last session he would not oppose the idea of a provision in the Bill that NMPs should not be appointed as Ministers.
